Posts.Content: patti41 wrote: Hello, I have so many questions and so much fear. My 16yr old daughter found a lump in her breast. We have been to the gyno, through an ultrasound and to a breast specialist. All agree it is a solid mass that must be removed. My rational mind tells me I shouldn't be worried, she is young and doesn't fit the profile. However there is a side of me that is in total panic. We have a strong history of cancer in our family, great grandmother breast cancer at a young age, both grandparents died fairly young of cancer. My daughter herself had an extensive medical history...kidney disorder, hypothyroidism, long extended menstrual cycles, cysts on the ovaries, crazy infections and just recently had her gallbladder removed as it was only functioning at 5%. Most don't experience all this until later in life...Now the lump! Here are my questions...is it possible or has anyone ever heard of a teenager with breast cancer? What are the odds? I have heard that generally breast cancer lumps don't hurt? Is that true? Please help...find information on teens and breast cancer is not an easy task! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2007 08:04AM patti41 wrote: I have been reading some of the messages on this board. Now I'm really confused. So many are stating they are waiting so long for answers and appointments or being told to wait 6 months to be rechecked. My daughters first appointment was last week at the gyno, next day ultrasound 2 days later breast specialist...Wednesday she will have her lump removed. I'm now wondering if my daughters doctors are really concerned and not saying??? Or are we just lucky with medical care??? Why is this moving so fast for her and so many others are waiting for long periods of time? We have only been in panic mode for a week, I can't imagine worrying for 6 months.
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2007 05:29AM patti41 wrote: Totally confused - We just got back from seeing the 2nd specialist. Her view was much different than the 1st. She suggested waiting 3 months before doing anything to see if there are any changes. She stated there was a solid mass but sometimes over time there is a "softening". Sometimes there are changes with menstrual cycles. Which in some cases I would say yes but according to my daughter she has had the lump for sometime now...approx 3-4 months. So far there have been no changes. However, this doctor made me feel like having the lump removed was not necessary right and may not be necessary later. All the information we have received is very confusing! We are rescheduled to have the lump removed next week and now I'm not sure what to do. A 3rd opinion???? I guess my next thought is...if I had a lump anywhere on my body that didn't belong, I would probably have it out!
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2007 07:20AM patti41 wrote: Sorry forgot to answer your first question...the 1st specialist stated that because she is so dense and they had a hard time seeing the lump on the ultrasound they could only go by a physical exam. According to both Dr's the Lump is a solid mass and it is hard to determine what type of mass. They both agree it does not move free...(unsure what that means) They both agree it is not a cyst and it is not a perfect round size...Anyway the first dr. stated the only way to tell exactly what we were dealing with was to take it out.
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL
Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2007 03:57AM patti41 wrote: Thank you for your kind words! Luckily my daughter is very positive (nervous but positive) She told me everything happens for a reason and she has already found her reason. My daughter is a cheerleader, we shared her story with her coach as my daughter will not be able to cheer for a couple of weeks after the lump is removed. Anyway her coach who is 26, was concerned, she also expressed she thought very little about breast exams or breast health. My daughter and her coach decided to take time out of practice to discuss the importance of breast health and self breast exams. It was amazing that not many teens never think about it. They were all shocked and many stated it only happens in older people. Hopefully my daughters experience will help other girls! In the meantime she now has the support of her whole team...they will be there for her to celebrate when the new is all good! Either way her spirits are high! I figure I will do the worrying!!! Let her have fun!
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2007 06:02AM patti41 wrote: You hit the nail on the head...she is rare in so many ways!Most of them awesome! We often joke "if it's gonna happen it's gonna happen to her"...at least she can laugh and turn it into a positive. I probably wouldn't be worried if she didn't have so many other health issue with a family history of cancer.
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2007 06:11PM patti41 wrote: I'm already scared...at this point I will take all the information I can get. At this point, I want to make sure we are taking all the right steps and looking at all options. Thank you
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL
Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2007 07:57AM patti41 wrote: Teenagers? Got to her primary doctor...no fever! Go figure! Said she probably has a little bug! Everything happens for a reason...I received a message today from another breast specialist today, they have a cancellation for tomorrow and can fit my daughter in. This was the doctor I originally wanted but they were unavailable for a 6 weeks. I guess it can't hurt to have another opinion. Of course my daughter is not happy about going to another doctor. She said she is tired of being felt up and just wants "it" out! I think another opinion may be a good idea.
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL
Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2007 04:02AM patti41 wrote: My daughters father is jewish and both of his parents died at a fairly young age of cancer. Where do I find more information on the genetic testing? Patti

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2007 07:11AM patti41 wrote: Very good question? I actually just called both Dr's (of course left a message) to learn more about the core biopsy and to see if that is an option. My daughter is complaining that the lump is sore all the time, she wants it out as it bothers her. I just want what ever is best for her. I've been through so many medical things with her in the past...I never remember being this confuse...so much information...it seems no two people, breasts, situations are the same! I'm on information overload.
Posts.Title: Scared for my teen patti41 SWANKETTEGAL

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2007 09:09AM patti41 wrote: Beth...thanks so much for the websites...I will check them both out. I'm really going to consider the genetic testing...my daughter has had so many medical issues. Sad to say her grandmother had many of the same problems my daughter was diagnosed with...we always joke and say...she got it from Grandma. Thanks again.
